00010 #if !defined(GEOGRAPHICLIB_ALBERSEQUALAREA_HPP)
00011 #define GEOGRAPHICLIB_ALBERSEQUALAREA_HPP "$Id: eee2b79bf8f65888c9a3b75a6b5be04ada04e985 $"

00013 #include <algorithm>
00014 #include <GeographicLib/Constants.hpp>
00015 
00016 namespace GeographicLib {
00017 
00018   /**
00019    * \brief Albers Equal Area Conic Projection
00020    *
00021    * Implementation taken from the report,
00022    * - J. P. Snyder,
00023    *   <a href="http://pubs.er.usgs.gov/usgspubs/pp/pp1395"> Map Projections: A
00024    *   Working Manual</a>, USGS Professional Paper 1395 (1987),
00025    *   pp. 101&ndash;102.
00026    *
00027    * This is a implementation of the equations in Snyder except that divided
00028    * differences will be [have been] used to transform the expressions into
00029    * ones which may be evaluated accurately.  [In this implementation, the
00030    * projection correctly becomes the cylindrical equal area or the azimuthal
00031    * equal area projection when the standard latitude is the equator or a
00032    * pole.]
00033    *
00034    * The ellipsoid parameters, the standard parallels, and the scale on the
00035    * standard parallels are set in the constructor.  Internally, the case with
00036    * two standard parallels is converted into a single standard parallel, the
00037    * latitude of minimum azimuthal scale, with an azimuthal scale specified on
00038    * this parallel.  This latitude is also used as the latitude of origin which
00039    * is returned by AlbersEqualArea::OriginLatitude.  The azimuthal scale on
00040    * the latitude of origin is given by AlbersEqualArea::CentralScale.  The
00041    * case with two standard parallels at opposite poles is singular and is
00042    * disallowed.  The central meridian (which is a trivial shift of the
00043    * longitude) is specified as the \e lon0 argument of the
00044    * AlbersEqualArea::Forward and AlbersEqualArea::Reverse functions.
00045    * AlbersEqualArea::Forward and AlbersEqualArea::Reverse also return the
00046    * meridian convergence, \e gamma, and azimuthal scale, \e k.  A small square
00047    * aligned with the cardinal directions is projected to a rectangle with
00048    * dimensions \e k (in the E-W direction) and 1/\e k (in the N-S direction).
00049    * The E-W sides of the rectangle are oriented \e gamma degrees
00050    * counter-clockwise from the \e x axis.  There is no provision in this class
00051    * for specifying a false easting or false northing or a different latitude
00052    * of origin.
00053    **********************************************************************/
00054   class GEOGRAPHIC_EXPORT AlbersEqualArea {
00055   private:
00056     typedef Math::real real;
00057     real _a, _f, _fm, _e2, _e, _e2m, _qZ, _qx;
00058     real _sign, _lat0, _k0;
00059     real _n0, _m02, _nrho0, _k2, _txi0, _scxi0, _sxi0;
00060     static const real eps_;
00061     static const real epsx_;
00062     static const real epsx2_;
00063     static const real tol_;
00064     static const real tol0_;
00065     static const real ahypover_;
00066     static const int numit_ = 5;   // Newton iterations in Reverse
00067     static const int numit0_ = 20; // Newton iterations in Init
00068     static inline real hyp(real x) throw() { return Math::hypot(real(1), x); }
00069     // atanh(      e   * x)/      e   if f > 0
00070     // atan (sqrt(-e2) * x)/sqrt(-e2) if f < 0
00071     // x                              if f = 0
00072     inline real atanhee(real x) const throw() {
00073       return _f > 0 ? Math::atanh(_e * x)/_e :
00074         (_f < 0 ? std::atan(_e * x)/_e : x);
00075     }
00076     // return atanh(sqrt(x))/sqrt(x) - 1, accurate for small x
00077     static real atanhxm1(real x) throw();
00078 
00079     // Divided differences
00080     // Definition: Df(x,y) = (f(x)-f(y))/(x-y)
00081     // See: W. M. Kahan and R. J. Fateman,
00082     // Symbolic computation of divided differences,
00083     // SIGSAM Bull. 33(3), 7-28 (1999)
00084     // http://doi.acm.org/10.1145/334714.334716
00085     // http://www.cs.berkeley.edu/~fateman/papers/divdiff.pdf
00086     //
00087     // General rules
00088     // h(x) = f(g(x)): Dh(x,y) = Df(g(x),g(y))*Dg(x,y)
00089     // h(x) = f(x)*g(x):
00090     //        Dh(x,y) = Df(x,y)*(g(x)+g(y))/2 + Dg(x,y)*(f(x)+f(y))/2
00091     //
00092     // sn(x) = x/sqrt(1+x^2): Dsn(x,y) = (x+y)/((sn(x)+sn(y))*(1+x^2)*(1+y^2))
00093     static inline real Dsn(real x, real y, real sx, real sy) throw() {
00094       // sx = x/hyp(x)
00095       real t = x * y;
00096       return t > 0 ? (x + y) * Math::sq( (sx * sy)/t ) / (sx + sy) :
00097         (x - y != 0 ? (sx - sy) / (x - y) : 1);
00098     }
00099     // Datanhee(x,y) = atanhee((x-y)/(1-e^2*x*y))/(x-y)
00100     inline real Datanhee(real x, real y) const throw() {
00101       real t = x - y, d = 1 - _e2 * x * y;
00102       return t != 0 ? atanhee(t / d) / t : 1 / d;
00103     }
00104     // DDatanhee(x,y) = (Datanhee(1,y) - Datanhee(1,x))/(y-x)
00105     real DDatanhee(real x, real y) const throw();
00106     void Init(real sphi1, real cphi1, real sphi2, real cphi2, real k1) throw();
00107     real txif(real tphi) const throw();
00108     real tphif(real txi) const throw();
00109   public:
00110 
00111     /**
00112      * Constructor with a single standard parallel.
00113      *
00114      * @param[in] a equatorial radius of ellipsoid (meters)
00115      * @param[in] f flattening of ellipsoid.  Setting \e f = 0 gives a sphere.
00116      *   Negative \e f gives a prolate ellipsoid.  If \e f > 1, set flattening
00117      *   to 1/\e f.
00118      * @param[in] stdlat standard parallel (degrees), the circle of tangency.
00119      * @param[in] k0 azimuthal scale on the standard parallel.
00120      *
00121      * An exception is thrown if \e a or \e k0 is not positive or if \e stdlat
00122      * is not in the range [-90, 90].
00123      **********************************************************************/
00124     AlbersEqualArea(real a, real f, real stdlat, real k0);
00125 
00126     /**
00127      * Constructor with two standard parallels.
00128      *
00129      * @param[in] a equatorial radius of ellipsoid (meters)
00130      * @param[in] f flattening of ellipsoid.  Setting \e f = 0 gives a sphere.
00131      *   Negative \e f gives a prolate ellipsoid.  If \e f > 1, set flattening
00132      *   to 1/\e f.
00133      * @param[in] stdlat1 first standard parallel (degrees).
00134      * @param[in] stdlat2 second standard parallel (degrees).
00135      * @param[in] k1 azimuthal scale on the standard parallels.
00136      *
00137      * An exception is thrown if \e a or \e k0 is not positive or if \e stdlat1
00138      * or \e stdlat2 is not in the range [-90, 90].  In addition, an exception
00139      * is thrown if \e stdlat1 and \e stdlat2 are opposite poles.
00140      **********************************************************************/
00141     AlbersEqualArea(real a, real f, real stdlat1, real stdlat2, real k1);
00142 
00143     /**
00144      * Constructor with two standard parallels specified by sines and cosines.
00145      *
00146      * @param[in] a equatorial radius of ellipsoid (meters)
00147      * @param[in] f flattening of ellipsoid.  Setting \e f = 0 gives a sphere.
00148      *   Negative \e f gives a prolate ellipsoid.  If \e f > 1, set flattening
00149      *   to 1/\e f.
00150      * @param[in] sinlat1 sine of first standard parallel.
00151      * @param[in] coslat1 cosine of first standard parallel.
00152      * @param[in] sinlat2 sine of second standard parallel.
00153      * @param[in] coslat2 cosine of second standard parallel.
00154      * @param[in] k1 azimuthal scale on the standard parallels.
00155      *
00156      * This allows parallels close to the poles to be specified accurately.
00157      * This routine computes the latitude of origin and the azimuthal scale at
00158      * this latitude.  If \e dlat = abs(\e lat2 - \e lat1) <= 160<sup>o</sup>,
00159      * then the error in the latitude of origin is less than
00160      * 4.5e-14<sup>o</sup>.
00161      **********************************************************************/
00162     AlbersEqualArea(real a, real f,
00163                     real sinlat1, real coslat1,
00164                     real sinlat2, real coslat2,
00165                     real k1);
00166 
00167     /**
00168      * Set the azimuthal scale for the projection.
00169      *
00170      * @param[in] lat (degrees).
00171      * @param[in] k azimuthal scale at latitude \e lat (default 1).
00172      *
00173      * This allows a "latitude of conformality" to be specified.  An exception
00174      * is thrown if \e k is not positive or if \e lat is not in the range (-90,
00175      * 90).
00176      **********************************************************************/
00177     void SetScale(real lat, real k = real(1));
00178 
00179     /**
00180      * Forward projection, from geographic to Lambert conformal conic.
00181      *
00182      * @param[in] lon0 central meridian longitude (degrees).
00183      * @param[in] lat latitude of point (degrees).
00184      * @param[in] lon longitude of point (degrees).
00185      * @param[out] x easting of point (meters).
00186      * @param[out] y northing of point (meters).
00187      * @param[out] gamma meridian convergence at point (degrees).
00188      * @param[out] k azimuthal scale of projection at point; the radial
00189      *   scale is the 1/\e k.
00190      *
00191      * The latitude origin is given by AlbersEqualArea::LatitudeOrigin().  No
00192      * false easting or northing is added and \e lat should be in the range
00193      * [-90, 90]; \e lon and \e lon0 should be in the range [-180, 360].  The
00194      * values of \e x and \e y returned for points which project to infinity
00195      * (i.e., one or both of the poles) will be large but finite.
00196      **********************************************************************/
00197     void Forward(real lon0, real lat, real lon,
00198                  real& x, real& y, real& gamma, real& k) const throw();
00199 
00200     /**
00201      * Reverse projection, from Lambert conformal conic to geographic.
00202      *
00203      * @param[in] lon0 central meridian longitude (degrees).
00204      * @param[in] x easting of point (meters).
00205      * @param[in] y northing of point (meters).
00206      * @param[out] lat latitude of point (degrees).
00207      * @param[out] lon longitude of point (degrees).
00208      * @param[out] gamma meridian convergence at point (degrees).
00209      * @param[out] k azimuthal scale of projection at point; the radial
00210      *   scale is the 1/\e k.
00211      *
00212      * The latitude origin is given by AlbersEqualArea::LatitudeOrigin().  No
00213      * false easting or northing is added.  \e lon0 should be in the range
00214      * [-180, 360].  The value of \e lon returned is in the range [-180, 180).
00215      * The value of \e lat returned is in the range [-90,90].  If the input
00216      * point is outside the legal projected space the nearest pole is returned.
00217      **********************************************************************/
00218     void Reverse(real lon0, real x, real y,
00219                  real& lat, real& lon, real& gamma, real& k) const throw();
00220 
00221     /**
00222      * AlbersEqualArea::Forward without returning the convergence and
00223      * scale.
00224      **********************************************************************/
00225     void Forward(real lon0, real lat, real lon,
00226                  real& x, real& y) const throw() {
00227       real gamma, k;
00228       Forward(lon0, lat, lon, x, y, gamma, k);
00229     }
00230 
00231     /**
00232      * AlbersEqualArea::Reverse without returning the convergence and
00233      * scale.
00234      **********************************************************************/
00235     void Reverse(real lon0, real x, real y,
00236                  real& lat, real& lon) const throw() {
00237       real gamma, k;
00238       Reverse(lon0, x, y, lat, lon, gamma, k);
00239     }
00240 
00241     /** \name Inspector functions
00242      **********************************************************************/
00243     ///@{
00244     /**
00245      * @return \e a the equatorial radius of the ellipsoid (meters).  This is
00246      *   the value used in the constructor.
00247      **********************************************************************/
00248     Math::real MajorRadius() const throw() { return _a; }
00249 
00250     /**
00251      * @return \e f the flattening of the ellipsoid.  This is the value used in
00252      *   the constructor.
00253      **********************************************************************/
00254     Math::real Flattening() const throw() { return _f; }
00255 
00256     /**
00257      * <b>DEPRECATED</b>
00258      * @return \e r the inverse flattening of the ellipsoid.
00259      **********************************************************************/
00260     Math::real InverseFlattening() const throw() { return 1/_f; }
00261 
00262     /**
00263      * @return latitude of the origin for the projection (degrees).
00264      *
00265      * This is the latitude of minimum azimuthal scale and equals the \e stdlat
00266      * in the 1-parallel constructor and lies between \e stdlat1 and \e stdlat2
00267      * in the 2-parallel constructors.
00268      **********************************************************************/
00269     Math::real OriginLatitude() const throw() { return _lat0; }
00270 
00271     /**
00272      * @return central scale for the projection.  This is the azimuthal scale
00273      *   on the latitude of origin.
00274      **********************************************************************/
00275     Math::real CentralScale() const throw() { return _k0; }
00276     ///@}
00277 
00278     /**
00279      * A global instantiation of AlbersEqualArea with the WGS84 ellipsoid, \e
00280      * stdlat = 0, and \e k0 = 1.  This degenerates to the cylindrical equal
00281      * area projection.
00282      **********************************************************************/
00283     static const AlbersEqualArea CylindricalEqualArea;
00284 
00285     /**
00286      * A global instantiation of AlbersEqualArea with the WGS84 ellipsoid, \e
00287      * stdlat = 90<sup>o</sup>, and \e k0 = 1.  This degenerates to the
00288      * Lambert azimuthal equal area projection.
00289      **********************************************************************/
00290     static const AlbersEqualArea AzimuthalEqualAreaNorth;
00291 
00292     /**
00293      * A global instantiation of AlbersEqualArea with the WGS84 ellipsoid, \e
00294      * stdlat = -90<sup>o</sup>, and \e k0 = 1.  This degenerates to the
00295      * Lambert azimuthal equal area projection.
00296      **********************************************************************/
00297     static const AlbersEqualArea AzimuthalEqualAreaSouth;
00298   };
00299 
00300 } // namespace GeographicLib
